Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Concrete is protected against frost damage by adding surfactants (called air-entraining agents, AEA) that stabilize air voids, which serve to accommodate the volume expansion as pore water freezes and to create suction in the unfrozen pore water that offsets the pressure exerted on pore walls by ice crystals. The goal of the proposed work is to optimize the performance of entrained air voids. We will study the interaction of commercial AEA and other surfactants with cement paste to obtain quantitative information about the rate and extent of adsorption of AEA on air bubbles, and the rate of growth and pore size of the lime-rich shells that form on their surfaces. The adsorption kinetics will be studied by tensiometry, which quantifies the change in concentration of the surfactant in the solution. Compressibility measurements at near-atmospheric pressure will quantify the rigidity of the shells as they evolve. To examine the microstructure of delicate early-age hydration products, we will use supercritical drying to remove the pore liquid without creating capillary pressure. This will produce unaltered structures for examination by nitrogen sorption and electron microscopy. The results will be used to interpret dilatometric curves obtained during freezing of cement paste and mortar. Dilatation during freezing depends on the nucleation behavior, which will be manipulated by incorporation of a nucleating agent (metaldehyde), and on the ability of the air voids to confine ice inside, which depends on the pore size in the shell.
The project will provide a sound basis for choosing chemical additives that optimize the frost protection of concrete, and a methodology for evaluating new organic additives. By improving the frost resistance of concrete, the cost of maintaining the civil infrastructure will be reduced, and the emissions of CO2 will be decreased, because less cement will be required for replacement of structures. The introduction of new methods for studying the process of air entrainment, and for preparing artifact-free samples for analysis, will open new avenues of research in materials science. The tensiometric method for evaluating air voids could replace less quantitative procedures currently used in industry. This work will contribute to the education of a female graduate student and post-doctoral researcher, and will provide topics for undergraduate independent research, senior theses, and REU/RET projects.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Concrete is, and will continue to be, the most widely used construction material, so its durability has a huge social and financial impact. Concrete infrastructure is protected from frost damage by incorporation of air bubbles that allow for the volume expansion as liquid water transforms into ice. Moreover, ice crystals that form inside the air voids suck water from the surrounding concrete and thereby pull the material into compression, which protects it from damage. This project examined the mechanisms by which commercial additives, called air-entraining agents (AEA), provide protection. One of our goals was to identify features of the molecules that make them effective, so that superior products could be designed. Using a technique called tensiometry, Lori Tunstall showed that the most efficient products were those that associate most strongly with one another. The ecological impact of concrete is reduced by incorporating fly ash (a by-product of burning coal) along with the cement; however, the ash is often contaminated with carbon, which can interfere with air entrainment. Therefore, another objective was to understand how carbon contamination affects air void formation. Ms. Tunstall made the important discovery that the AEA adsorb strongly onto the glassy fly ashparticles, but the carbon forms a shell around the particles that prevents the additives from interacting with the water to form bubbles. This means that grinding or oxidizing the powders to crush the carbon shells could reduce the variability in performance caused by the contamination. The final goal was to measure the effect of AEA on the dimensional change of cementitious samples during freezing: if the samples contract during freezing, then the net stresses must be compressive, so damage is unlikely, but if they expand, then the ice is causing pressure that can result in cracking. Ms. Tunstall showed that a proper dose of the additives could provide protection at temperatures as low as -50ºC. Most  importantly, these experiments confirmed that the suction created by ice in the air voids produces contraction of the material, and that spontaneous formation of ice (by a process called homogeneous nucleation) results in destructive expansion upon cooling to -40ºC unless the dosage of the additive is sufficient (and much higher than what is typically used). In addition, we implemented a novel process, supercritical drying using trifluoromethane, to obtain samples of cement paste undamaged by the capillary pressure that usually occurs during drying. This work, achieved by Dr Zhidong Zhang, provided the most detailed look yet at the ultimate microstructure of hydrated cement. This information will guide theoretical modeling of the hydration process of cement, which is essential for prediction of the long-term performance of the material.


Last Modified: 07/21/2017
Modified by: George W Scherer
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Concrete is, and will continue to be, the most widely used construction material, so its durability has a huge social and financial impact. Concrete infrastructure is protected from frost damage by incorporation of air bubbles that allow for the volume expansion as liquid water transforms into ice. Moreover, ice crystals that form inside the air voids suck water from the surrounding concrete and thereby pull the material into compression, which protects it from damage. This project examined the mechanisms by which commercial additives, called air-entraining agents (AEA), provide protection. One of our goals was to identify features of the molecules that make them effective, so that superior products could be designed. Using a technique called tensiometry, Lori Tunstall showed that the most efficient products were those that associate most strongly with one another. The ecological impact of concrete is reduced by incorporating fly ash (a by-product of burning coal) along with the cement; however, the ash is often contaminated with carbon, which can interfere with air entrainment. Therefore, another objective was to understand how carbon contamination affects air void formation. Ms. Tunstall made the important discovery that the AEA adsorb strongly onto the glassy fly ashparticles, but the carbon forms a shell around the particles that prevents the additives from interacting with the water to form bubbles. This means that grinding or oxidizing the powders to crush the carbon shells could reduce the variability in performance caused by the contamination. The final goal was to measure the effect of AEA on the dimensional change of cementitious samples during freezing: if the samples contract during freezing, then the net stresses must be compressive, so damage is unlikely, but if they expand, then the ice is causing pressure that can result in cracking. Ms. Tunstall showed that a proper dose of the additives could provide protection at temperatures as low as -50ºC. Most importantly, these experiments confirmed that the suction created by ice in the air voids produces contraction of the material, and that spontaneous formation of ice (by a process called homogeneous nucleation) results in destructive expansion upon cooling to -40ºC unless the dosage of the additive is sufficient (and much higher than what is typically used). In addition, we implemented a novel process, supercritical drying using trifluoromethane, to obtain samples of cement paste undamaged by the capillary pressure that usually occurs during drying. This work, achieved by Dr Zhidong Zhang, provided the most detailed look yet at the ultimate microstructure of hydrated cement. This information will guide theoretical modeling of the hydration process of cement, which is essential for prediction of the long-term performance of the material.
